sen.j: 徳麻呂（とこまろ、生没年不明）は、日本の飛鳥時代の人物である。
sen.e: Tokomaro (徳麻呂, date of birth and death unknown) is a Japanese who lived in Asuka period.
Tokomaro (date of birth and death unknown) lived during the Asuka period of Japan.
Tokomaro (date of birth and death unknown) lived during the Asuka period of Japan.
It also reads as 'Tokumaro.'
His name was also read as 'Tokumaro.'
His name was also read as 'Tokumaro.'

sen.e: The reading is the same in old Japanese syllabary characters.

The reading is the same in old Japanese syllabary characters.

sen.j: 大井寺の奴で、672年の壬申の乱のとき大海人皇子側の軍勢に加わり、大和の古道で大伴吹負の本営を支えた。
sen.e: He was a servant to Oi-ji Temple, joined the troops from Oama no Miko (Prince Oama) in the Jinshin War in 672, and supported the headquarters of OTOMO no Fukei on Yamato no kodo (the ancient paths in Yamato Province).

He was Yatsuko (or Yakko, servant) of Oi-dera Temple, and in the Jinshin War of 672, he joined the Army of Oama no Miko (Prince Oama), and guarded the main camp of the OTOMO no Fukei's force at the old road of Yamato.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。「古道」は固有名詞ではなく、特別重要な言葉でもないので普通の訳にします。「大井寺」は「おおいでら」。
sen.e: He was Yatsuko (or Yakko, servant) of Oi-dera Temple, and in the Jinshin War of 672, he joined the Army of Oama no Miko (Prince Oama), and guarded the main camp of the OTOMO no Fukei's force at the old road of Yamato.

sen.j: 徳麻呂の名は、『日本書紀』が記す倭（大和国）の中道（なかつみち）での戦闘中に現れる。
sen.e: Tokomaro is mentioned in "the Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) in a chapter on the battle on Nakatsu-michi Road (one of the three Kamakura-kaido Road) in Wa (Yamato Province).
sen.cmt: ”戦闘中に現れる”を、”戦闘の章に現れる”のように、”章”という語を補って訳しています。
sen.e: Tokomaro is mentioned in the scene of the battle at Naka-tsu-michi Road of Yamato (Yamato Province), in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミス、固有名詞読み間違いがあります。「倭」は「やまと」、「中道」の括弧内説明は不要です。
sen.e: Tokomaro is mentioned in the scene of the battle at Naka-tsu-michi Road of Yamato (Yamato Province), in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

sen.j: この戦いで大海人皇子（天武天皇）側の軍勢を率いた大伴吹負は、大和の古道に配した部隊のうち中道のものを直接指揮していた。
sen.e: In the battle, OTOMO no Fukei who led the troops from Oama no Miko (Emperor Tenmu) directly commanded a troop on Nakatsu-michi Road which was one of the troops deployed in Yamato no kodo.

In the battle, OTOMO no Fukei, who was leading the troops to support Oama no Miko (Prince Oama, later became Emperor Tenmu), directly commanded a troop on Naka-tsu-michi Road which was one of the troops he had deployed in the old roads of Yamato.
sen.cmt: 訳語を統一、わかりやすくします。
sen.e: In the battle, OTOMO no Fukei, who was leading the troops to support Oama no Miko (Prince Oama, later became Emperor Tenmu), directly commanded a troop on Naka-tsu-michi Road which was one of the troops he had deployed in the old roads of Yamato.

sen.j: 徳麻呂ら大井寺の奴5人はその中にいた。
sen.e: The five servants from Oi-ji Temple including Tokomaro were in the troop.
The five servants of Oi-dera Temple including Tokomaro were in the troop.
sen.cmt: 固有名詞読み間違いがあります。
sen.e: The five servants of Oi-dera Temple including Tokomaro were in the troop.

sen.j: 対して、敵将犬養五十君は廬井鯨に二百の精兵を与えて吹負の営を衝かせた。
sen.e: On the other hand, INUKAI no Ikimi, the enemy general, gave IOI no Kujira two hundreds warriors and made him attack Fukei troops.
To capture them, a commander of the enemy's troops, INUKAI no Ikimi gave IOI no Kujira two hundreds of selected warriors and ordered him to attack the Fukei's camp.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: To capture them, a commander of the enemy's troops, INUKAI no Ikimi gave IOI no Kujira two hundreds of selected warriors and ordered him to attack the Fukei's camp.

sen.j: そのとき吹負の周りには兵が少なく、襲撃を阻止することができなかった。
sen.e: At that time, there were not so many soldiers around Fukei that they couldn't obstruct the attack.
At that time, Fukei did not prepare many soldiers there, so couldn't repel the attack.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: At that time, Fukei did not prepare many soldiers there, so couldn't repel the attack.

sen.j: 徳麻呂ら5人はこのとき守備兵の先鋒となって進み出て、敵を射た。
sen.e: The five servants including Tokomaro voluntarily spearheaded the defensive army to shoot at the enemy.
The five servants including Tokomaro voluntarily spearheaded the guards and shot the enemy.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: The five servants including Tokomaro voluntarily spearheaded the guards and shot the enemy.

sen.j: これで鯨の軍の前進が止まった。
sen.e: This prevented Kujira from charging forward.
This prevented the Kujira's troop from charging the camp.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: This prevented the Kujira's troop from charging the camp.

sen.j: やがて上道で敵を破った三輪高市麻呂と置始兔の部隊が鯨の背後に回りこむと、鯨の部隊は敗走した。
sen.e: Before long, when the troop of MIWA no Takechimaro and OKISOME no Usagi sneaked around behind them, Kujira's troop was routed.

Soon after that, the troops of MIWA no Takechimaro and of OKISOME no Usagi who had defeated the enemy's troops at Kami-tsu-michi Road, attacked the Kujira's troop from behind, the Kujira's soldiers ran away.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ、訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: Soon after that, the troops of MIWA no Takechimaro and of OKISOME no Usagi who had defeated the enemy's troops at Kami-tsu-michi Road, attacked the Kujira's troop from behind, the Kujira's soldiers ran away.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』は壬申の乱について詳しく述べるが、一般兵士の身元まで記すはこの一箇所だけである。
sen.e: Though the details of the Jinshin War is given in "Nihonshoki", this is the only subject it mentions even identity of a regular soldier.
Although "Nihonshoki" describes the Jinshin War in detail, this is the only scene mentioning identity of a regular soldier.
Although "Nihonshoki" describes the Jinshin War in detail, this is the only scene mentioning identity of a regular soldier.

sen.j: 「大井寺奴」の4字は、兵士が民衆的な層から広く動員されたことを教える証拠であり、また、古代日本の奴（奴婢の男）が兵士として勇戦した例でもある。
sen.e: The four characters '大井寺奴' proves that common people were widely mobilized as soldiers, and this is also an example of ancient Japanese servants (male Nuhi [slave]) who fought bravely as soldiers.

This four characters '大井寺奴' (Oi-dera no Yatsuko [servants of Oi-dera Temple]) recorded in "Nihonshoki" proves that the common people were widely mobilized as soldiers, and this is also an example that Yatsuko (or Yakko, male slave) of ancient Japan fought bravely as soldiers.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミス、説明不足を補います。
sen.e: This four characters '大井寺奴' (Oi-dera no Yatsuko [servants of Oi-dera Temple]) recorded in "Nihonshoki" proves that the common people were widely mobilized as soldiers, and this is also an example that Yatsuko (or Yakko, male slave) of ancient Japan fought bravely as soldiers.
